answers.author: Amanda Dodge
answers.text:
Hi Pamela,
Unfortunately, I have been unable to find any best practices directly related to your question. However, I have been able to locate some local governments who have internet-based special events permit applications. 
Larimer County, Colorado seems to have a great application online. I attempted to contact the individual in the county’s planning department, but she is out of the office and has not been able to respond to my email. If you are interested in contacting the representative, her name is Linda Hoffman and her email address is lhoffmann@larimer.org. Here is what their application looks like:
http://www.co.larimer.co.us/specialevent/apply.cfm
Additionally, here are some other online applications that you might find useful. I attempted to email representatives from these areas as well, but received no response.
City of Los Angeles, CA:
http://bsspermits.lacity.org/spevents/
Iowa Department of Natural Resources:
https://programs.iowadnr.gov/specialevents/
Santa Clara County, CA:
http://www.sccgov.org/rda/permits/permits.preview.htm
I hope that this at least leads you in the right direction,
Amanda Dodge
International City/County Management Association
Knowledge Network Intern
202-962-3699
adodge@icma.org

answers.author: Frank Lancaster
answers.text:
Hi Pamela,
Sorry for the delay, but I'm glad Amanda ran across our system.  I think we do have a good online special events system that works well.  Our permit system is all online and self service and allows us to route event applications to numerous partner entities to comment and approve the events.  Each set is unique depending on the event.  Some, such as major bike races, may touch many jurisidictions.  Some may only require internal review, such as events at one of our parks.  The system seems to work for a variety of affected agencies from small rural volunteer EMS/fire services, to Colorado Dept. of Transportation.  The system also provides a subscription service for citizens to subscribe to notifications to events proposed in their neighborhood, based on zip code.  Citizens can also comment on events during the planning process.    We have worked with two cities in our county and now host mirror systems for their special events that don't require county permits.  Hopefully this consistency makes it easier for event promoters and citizens alike to apply for permits and to make sure all the bases are covered for major special events throughout the county.   I would probably be the best contact for more information, rather than our planning department.   They system covers some events that are covered by our land use code, but also events at county parks and open lands, and events using county roads.
Frank Lancaster
Larimer County Manager
